settings.text: As British Vogue’s Acting Shopping Director, Julia Brenard knows a thing or two about keeping her clothes in order. Here she shares her tips for tackling that wardrobe spring clean you may have been putting off.

settings.grid-content:
1. The big clear out

Because of my job, I do have quite a lot of clothes, so I try to have a clear out once a season and get rid of things that I am not wearing. I am probably not as strict as I should be – I am sure my boyfriend would agree – as I am quite sentimental. If you are not wearing something regularly then you have to ask yourself whether you get pleasure out of it, or whether it holds sentimental value, and if the answer is no then it is probably time to let it go.

I tend to gift things to friends – that way I feel like I am not saying goodbye to something forever. I also sell designer pieces on resale sites such as Vestiare Collective and Rebelle and give lots to charity shops.
settings.image-caption: Julia wears the Grey Cashmere Rollneck Sweater & matching Track Pants

settings.text:
2. Maximise your space

I recommend hanging as many of your clothes as possible because that way you can see exactly what you have. I like to group long items such as trousers, dresses, coats and jackets together, and then shorter items such as tops shorts and skirts.

It is best to fold jeans, T-shirts and jumpers in such a way that you can still tell what they are when they are stacked up, keeping defining details such as a print or interesting collar in view. This will make life easier when you are getting dressed in the morning.

I tend to swap things out of my wardrobe seasonally to use the available space to its full potential, for instance, I put my heavy winter coats and massive jumpers into sealed storage boxes in the loft over the summer months.

settings.grid-content:
3. Storage Essentials

try to use the skinniest hangers possible, any of my assistants will tell you that I hate big hangers on shoots because they just take up too much space. I worry about plastic hangers and the environment, so I opt for wooden or metal hangers.

If something is precious or expensive, then keep it in a clothes bag. I recently found out that the plastic ones attract moths, so fabric ones are better and better for the environment, too.



“I tend to gift things to friends – that way I feel like I’m not saying goodbye to something forever.”

4. All about accessories

I have dedicated shoe shelves and like to keep my nicer pairs laid out on display. I recommend keeping designer shoes that are not on display in their boxes and flat shoes and sandals in storage boxes – mine go under the bed.

I suggest stuffing your handbags with cloth bags to pad them out and help them keep their structure.

Rather than getting rid of shoes or bags that need a spruce up, I use the Restory - a great company that makes your worn-out accessories look as good as new.

5. Invest wisely

Once you have your wardrobe well organised, you can really begin to cherish the pieces you have and think carefully about what else you bring in. When shopping, ask yourself whether you love the item, if you are going to wear it often and whether it will fit with other pieces you already own…

I believe that investment pieces are more important now than ever. You should be looking for things that you are going to keep for a very long time, rather than frivolous throwaway items. Pieces like cashmere knits are great to invest in, so is a coat that will last you five years or longer, and a great pair of boots.
